prompt: In deontic logic, what is the 'ought-can' principle?
options: You can do whatever you ought to do
hint: 'Ought implies can' - a constraint on meaningful obligations.
explanation: The ought-can principle states O(p) → ◇p (ought implies can/possible). You cannot be obligated to do the impossible. If flying unaided is impossible, you can't be obligated to fly. This constrains what counts as a genuine obligation.
visual_concept: No one has a duty to turn lead into gold - it's impossible. Real obligations must be achievable.
